questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is the most effective extracellular buffer system at physiological pH?
questions.explanation:
The most effective extracellular buffer system at physiological pH is the bicarbonate buffer 
system. A molecule with a pKa close to the physiological pH (7.4) is considered an effective 
buffer. Although the pKa of HCO3- is relatively low (6.1), it makes up 92% of the plasma 
buffering. This is often attributed to the enormous quantity of HCO3- present in the body and the ability of 
this system to accept protons and form carbonic acid (H2CO3). This further in the presence of 
carbonic anhydrase is converted to readily excretable H■O and CO2. It is therefore considered the 
most efficient extracellular buffering system in the body. HCO3- + H+ H2CO3  H■O + CO2

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following is not done before drawing blood for arterial blood gas analysis?
questions.explanation:
Flexion of the wrist is not done just before drawing blood for ABG analysis. During arterial blood gas analysis, the ideal position for drawing arterial blood from the radial 
artery is to maintain the wrist in extension. This provides stability to the artery and prevents it 
from slipping away during the puncture. To draw blood for ABG analysis, the skin is pierced at 
a 45° angle. Allen's test is done prior to radial cannulation to identify the adequacy of radial and ulnar 
collateral blood flow to the hand. 35 
Sold by @itachibot The syringe used to draw blood for ABG analysis is rinsed with heparin prior to the 
procedure. Prior to collecting blood, 0.1 ml heparin is drawn into the syringe and then flushed 
out. The residue that lubricates the inner wall of the syringe is sufficient to prevent the blood from 
clotting.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not a cause of metabolic alkalosis?
questions.explanation:
Mineralocorticoid deficiency does not cause metabolic alkalosis. Its excess causes metabolic 
alkalosis. Causes of metabolic alkalosis: Loss of hydrogen: • Gastrointestinal loss • Removal of gastric secretions - vomiting or nasogastric suction • Chloride-losing diarrhea • Gastrocolic fistula • Villous adenoma • Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin • Renal loss • Loop or thiazide diuretics • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice) • Posthypercapnic states • Hypercalcemia, including milk-alkali syndrome • H+ movement into cells 36 
Sold by @itachibot • Hypokalemia Exogenous Alkali: • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids • Massive blood transfusion • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume): • Loop or thiazide-type diuretics • Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis • Gastric losses in achlorhydria Miscellaneous: • Bartter's syndrome • Gitelman's syndrome

questions.question: Question 4: Which metabolic abnormality are patients with bulimia nervosa least likely to develop?
questions.explanation:
The metabolic abnormality patients with bulimia nervosa are least likely to develop is metabolic 
acidosis. Chronic vomiting, as seen in bulimia nervosa leads to metabolic alkalosis, not acidosis. Conditions associated with chronic vomiting lead to hypochloremia, hyponatremia, hypokalemia, 
and metabolic alkalosis.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is false about metabolic alkalosis?

options.b: It is associated with decreased ionic calcium concentration
options.c: Can be caused due to Conn's syndrome
options.d: Can be caused due to a renin secreting tumor

questions.explanation:
Metabolic alkalosis is associated with potassium depletion, not hyperkalemia. While hypercalcemia can be a cause of metabolic alkalosis, alkalosis itself can cause a decrease in 
ionized calcium. The patients can present with tetany and show signs of hypocalcemia, i.e., 
Trousseau sign and Chvostek's sign. Conn's syndrome is primary hyperaldosteronism that leads to sodium reabsorption in exchange 
for hydrogen in the collecting ducts. This causes hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and hydrogen loss 
in urine and may lead to metabolic alkalosis. Renin-secreting tumors also lead to an increase in aldosterone levels leading to alkalosis. Causes of metabolic alkalosis: Loss of hydrogen: • Gastrointestinal loss • Removal of gastric secretions- vomiting or nasogastric suction • Chloride-losing diarrhea • Gastrocolic fistula 37 
Sold by @itachibot • Villous adenoma • Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin • Renal loss • Loop or thiazide diuretics • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice) • Posthypercapnic states • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome • • H+ movement into cells • Hypokalemia Exogenous Alkali: • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids • Massive blood transfusion • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume): • Loop or thiazide-type diuretics • Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis • Gastric losses in achlorhydria Miscellaneous: • Bartter's syndrome • Gitelman's syndrome

questions.question:
Question 7: The arterial blood gas analysis of a patient reveals a pH of 7.55, pCO2- 54 mmHg, and HCO3- 
40 mEq/L. What is the underlying disorder?

options.b: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
options.c: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
options.d: Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.explanation:
The underlying disorder in this patient is metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory 
acidosis. Interpretation of the ABG: Step 1: A pH of 7.55 indicates alkalosis. Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 40 mEq/L, which in the presence of a high pH indicates metabolic 
alkalosis. Step 3: pCO2 is 54 mmHg indicating respiratory acidosis. The increase in pCO2 along with the 
increase in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response. Step 4: Assessing the compensatory response: On average, the pCO2 rises 0.75 mmHg for every 1.0 mEq/L increment in the plasma HCO3- In the above scenario, the plasma HCO3- concentration is increased to 40 mEq/L (The average 
normal value is considered as 24 mEq/L) Thus, the HCO3- elevation is 40 – 24 = 16 mEq/L Therefore, pCO2 elevation should be 0.75 × 16 = 12 mmHg Now, considering that the average value of normal pCO2 is 40 mmHg, the estimated pCO2 
measured should be 40 + 12= 52 mmHg. As pCO2 is higher than the expected estimate, it is a case of metabolic alkalosis with 
compensatory respiratory acidosis.

questions.question:
Question 8: The arterial blood gas analysis of a 50-year-old diabetic patient revealed the following values: 
pH- 7.2 and HCO3- 15 mEq/L. Which of the following statements is false regarding renal 
compensation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The patient has low pH and decreased levels of bicarbonate which is indicative of metabolic 
acidosis. Bicarbonate reabsorption is increased in renal handling of metabolic acidosis. In response to metabolic acidosis, acidification of urine occurs by the following compensatory 
mechanisms: • The proximal tubule reabsorbs all the filtered HCO3- (as any loss of HCO3- is equal to the 
addition of an equimolar amount of H+). 39 
Sold by @itachibot • The collecting duct excretes the daily H+ load (loss of H+ is equal to the addition of an equimolar 
amount of HCO3-) primarily in the form of urinary ammonia.

questions.question:
Question 9: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Na+ = 137 mmol/L K+ = 4 mmol/L Cl- = 
100 mmol/L HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.explanation:
The anion gap is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated 
as: Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-]) Substituting the given values, AG is 22 mmol/L. Normal AG is 6 to 12 mmol/L with an average of 
10 mmol/L. The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical 
neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma. However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The 
cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl and HCO3. The value of plasma 
potassium is omitted from the calculation of the anion gap. Usually, the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations. The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall. The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions. The 
unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium, and potassium.

questions.question: Question 10: In which of the following patients would you expect to find an increased anion gap?
questions.explanation:
The anion gap is increased in ketoacidosis. The ketone bodies act as unmeasured anions and 
increase the anion gap. The anion gap is calculated as: AG = (Na+) – [(Cl-) + (HCO3-)] The normal anion gap is 6 - 12 mEq/L (optimally <10 mEq/L).

questions.question:
Question 11: High anion gap acidosis with low bicarbonate levels is seen in all the following conditions 
except:
questions.explanation:
Renal tubular acidosis causes normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, not high anion gap acidosis. Normally, in the serum, the total number of cations is equal to the total number of anions. But, a 
few of the anionic proteins (e.g., albumin), phosphates, sulfates, and organic anions are not 
measured and this is called an anion gap. It is the difference between measured cations and 
measured anions and is estimated as: Plasma anion gap = [Na+] ([Cl-]+[HCO3-]) The normal anion gap ranges between 6-12 mEq/L. 40 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: A 40-year-old man presented with nausea, dizziness, and hyperventilation. His arterial blood 
gas analysis and serum electrolyte levels revealed metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap. 29 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is the possible reason for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap is a feature of renal tubular acidosis. Renal tubular acidosis is a form of hyperchloraemic metabolic acidosis which occurs when the 
renal damage primarily affects tubular function without much effect on glomerular function. The 
bicarbonate loss leading to acidosis is mirrored by an increase in chloride concentration. Hence 
the unmeasured anions are unaffected and thus, the anion gap remains within normal limits. The result is a decrease in H+ excretion which is greater than that can be explained by any change 
in the glomerular filtration rate (GFR). However, if the GFR is significantly depressed eg., renal 
failure, the retention of fixed acids leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.question:
Question 14: A patient with chronic kidney disease came with complaints of vomiting and diarrhea. His 
blood gas reports show pH = 7.40, HCO3- = 23 mEq/L, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L. 
What is your probable diagnosis?

options.d: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

questions.explanation:
The probable diagnosis is a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) with metabolic alkalosis. Interpretation of the ABG: Step 1: The pH being 7.4 is within normal limits. 41 
Sold by @itachibot Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 23 mEq/L and again is within normal limits. At this juncture, we have ruled out options B and C as this particular clinical scenario is not 
suggestive of a simple acid-base disorder. Step 3: Calculating the Anion gap: Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-]) = 145-(100+23) = 22 mEq/L The presence of a high anion gap indicates that there's indeed an acid-base disorder, thus ruling 
out option A. A high anion gap indicates metabolic acidosis. However, HCO3- levels within normal limits 
suggest that there is also coexisting metabolic alkalosis in this patient. This can be confirmed by calculating the delta gap. Delta gap = AG - HCO3- In this scenario: Delta gap = (22-10) - (24-23) = 11 mEq/L Delta gap is > +6 suggesting the presence of metabolic alkalosis along with HAGMA. If the delta gap is significantly positive (>+6), metabolic alkalosis is present because the rise in 
the anion gap is more than the fall in bicarbonate. If the delta gap is significantly negative (<6) 
then hyperchloremic acidosis is usually present because a rise in the anion gap is less than a fall in 
bicarbonate. Alternatively, this can be confirmed by calculating the delta ratio. Delta ratio = the increase in Anion Gap / the decrease in HCO3- It is used in the presence of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), to check it is a ‘pure’ 
HAGMA or if there is coexistant normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) or metabolic 
alkalosis. Delta ratio values: • 1-2 indicates HAGMA • < 1 indicates NAGMA + HAGMA • > 2 indicates HAGMA + Metabolic alkalosis In this scenario, Delta ratio = 12/1 = 12 Thus, the acid-base disorder for the above scenario is HAGMA with metabolic alkalosis.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 5-year-old boy presents with generalized edema. Urine analysis showed protein 3+ and fat 
bodies. Which of the following would you expect to see in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome. This leads to a decrease in serum 
albumin which is an unmeasured anion. 42 
Sold by @itachibot Albumin at physiological pH is the major contributor to the unmeasured anions of the body. 
Unmeasured anions consume bicarbonate in the body and reduce its levels. This leads to an 
increase in the anion gap. Therefore, when these unmeasured anions are reduced the anion gap 
also reduces due to decreased consumption of the bicarbonate. Nephrotic syndrome causes hypoalbuminemia and thus patients have a reduced anion gap. A fall 
in serum albumin by 1 g/dL from the normal value (4.5 g/dL) decreases the anion gap by 2.5 
mEq/L. Decreased anion gap (<6 mEq/L) is seen in: • Increase in unmeasured cations • An addition of abnormal cations to the blood, such as: • Lithium (lithium intoxication) • Cationic immunoglobulins (plasma cell dyscrasias) • Reduction in the plasma anion albumin concentration (nephrotic syndrome, liver disease, or 
malabsorption) • Bromide intoxication • Hyperviscosity and severe hyperlipidemia, which can lead to an underestimation of sodium and 
chloride concentrations.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 54-year-old male patient with renal failure has missed a round of dialysis. He complains of 
lethargy, anorexia, and vomiting. What is the probable acid-base disorder that we can expect 
in him?

options.b: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis

questions.explanation:
In renal failure, there is a loss of kidney function due to the damage affecting glomeruli and 
tubules. This leads to a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.question:
Question 17: ABG analysis of a patient is shown below. What is the probable underlying acid-base disorder 
in this patient?

options.a: Metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis
options.b: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory acidosis
options.c: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis

questions.explanation:
The underlying acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with compensatory 
respiratory alkalosis. Interpretation of the ABG: Step 1: A pH of 7.1 signifies acidosis. Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 6 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis. Step 3: pCO2 is 16 mmHg indicating respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in pCO2 along with the 
decrease in pH suggests that this is a compensatory response. Step 4: The expected compensatory decrease in pCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula 
(Expected PCO2= {[1.5 x HCO3-] +8} ± 2). Expected PCO2 = {[1.5 x 6] +8} ± 2 = 15 to 19 mmHg A pCO2 level of 16 mmHg falls within the range given above. Hence, metabolic acidosis 
is associated with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. 43 
Sold by @itachibot (pCO2 values above or below 15 - 19 mmHg would indicate mixed acid-base disorders) Alternatively: The other method to calculate the expected compensation is a 1.2 mmHg decrease in pCO2 for 
every 1 mmol/L decrease in bicarbonate. The decrease in bicarbonate is 24 - 6 = 18 mEq/L Decrease in pCO2 is 18 x 1.2 = 22 Expected pCO2 = 40 - 22 = 18 mmHg (roughly = 16 mmHg since the standard values are 
approximations) This method also indicates primary metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis. 
However, Winter's formula is more accurate.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with dyspnea, and altered 
sensorium. These symptoms were preceded by an asthma attack. What is the probable reason 
for the patient's presenting symptoms?
questions.explanation:
The probable reason for the patient's presenting symptoms is respiratory acidosis. Asthma attack leads to the narrowing of respiratory passages. This leads to reduced O2 inhalation 
and reduced CO2 exhalation contributing to the rise of pCO2 in the blood, thereby 
causing respiratory acidosis. Causes of respiratory acidosis: • Central: • Drugs (anesthetics, morphine, sedatives) • Stroke • Infection • Airway: • Obstruction • Asthma • Lung parenchyma: • Emphysema • Pneumoconiosis • Bronchitis • Adult respiratory distress syndrome • Barotrauma • Neuromuscular: • Poliomyelitis • Kyphoscoliosis • Myasthenia 44 
Sold by @itachibot • Muscular dystrophies • Miscellaneous: • Obesity • Hypoventilation • Permissive hypercapnia.

questions.question:
Question 19: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease presents with 
increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis is as shown. What is the most probable 
underlying acid-base disorder?
questions.explanation:
The underlying acid-base disorder is respiratory acidosis. Interpretation of the ABG: Step 1: A pH of 7.24 signifies acidosis. Step 2: A plasma HCO3- is 27 mEq/L is within normal limits. This is very likely to be due to 
compensation as it does not reflect the direction of the pH change. Step 3: A pCO2 of 60 mmHg along with an acidotic pH signifies respiratory acidosis. Step 4: The expected compensatory increase in HCO3- can be calculated using the following 
formula: Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 š  PaCO2 (as COPD is a chronic condition and the presentation of the 
patient is not acute) Thus, the increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x (60-40) = 8 mEq/L Therefore expected HCO3- is 24 + 8 = 32 mEq/L. The actual HCO3- measured is 27 mEq/L (which is less than the expected value) indicating 
that there could be a component of metabolic acidosis also. But, the predominant disorder is respiratory acidosis and thus it is the best answer.

questions.question:
Question 20: A young asthmatic boy was rushed to ED with confusion and gasping for breath. His ABG 
analysis is as shown. What is the acid-base disorder?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute severe asthma. The acid-base disorder is 
respiratory acidosis, partially compensated. Interpretation of the ABG: Step 1: pH is decreased. This signifies acidosis. In acidosis, either pCO2 is increased or plasma 
HCO3- is decreased. Step 2: In this case, pCO2 is increased by 30 mmHg. This signifies respiratory acidosis. Step 3: Plasma HCO3- is increased by 26-24 = 2 mEq/L. This signifies compensation is taking 
place. In acute conditions, for every 10mmHg rise in pCO2 expected rise in plasma HCO3- is 1mEq/L. In 
this case, pCO2 has risen by 30 mmHg, so the expected rise in HCO3- is 3 mEq/L. 45 
Sold by @itachibot However, plasma HCO3- has risen only by 2 mEq/L, which implies compensation is only partial.

questions.question:
Question 21: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The above findings give the diagnosis of respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation. Interpretation of the ABG: Step 1: pH is reduced (7.12), hence acidosis. Step 2: Since pCO2 is raised (50 mmHg), it is respiratory acidosis. Step 3: HCO3 is raised (28 mEq/L) suggesting there is metabolic compensation.

questions.question:
Question 22: A 40-year-old woman was rushed to the ER with chest pain, palpitations, and sweating. On 
examination, her respiratory rate was 32/min, and carpopedal spasm was noted while 
measuring BP. Her ECG was normal. Which of the following acid-base disorders is she likely 
to have?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a panic attack. The patient is likely to have respiratory 
alkalosis. Panic attacks are characterized by hyperventilation which leads to a washout of CO2 (reduced 
PaCO2). This further increases the ratio of bicarbonate concentration to PaCO2 and, thereby, 
increases the pH level causing alkalosis. Alkalosis promotes the binding of calcium to albumin and reduces the fraction of ionized calcium 
in the blood. This leads to hypocalcemia without reducing the total calcium levels. Thus, alkalosis 
can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm, especially in calcium-deficient patients. Induction of carpopedal spasm when the BP cuff is inflated 20 mm Hg over the systolic BP for 
three minutes or more is called Trousseau sign. It is a clinical manifestation of hypocalcemia. Causes of respiratory alkalosis: • Central nervous system stimulation: • Pain • Anxiety, psychosis • Fever • Cerebrovascular accident • meningitis, encephalitis • Tumor • Trauma • Hypoxemia or tissue hypoxia: • High altitude • Pneumonia, pulmonary edema • Aspiration • Severe anemia 46 
Sold by @itachibot • Drugs or hormones: • Pregnancy • Salicylates • Cardiac failure • Stimulation of chest receptors: • Hemothorax • Flail chest • Cardiac failure • Pulmonary embolism • Miscellaneous: • Septicemia • Hepatic failure • Mechanical hyperventilation • Heat exposure • Recovery from metabolic acidosis Note: While metabolic alkalosis can also cause hypocalcemia, the above scenario of 
hyperventilation is more suggestive of respiratory alkalosis. Furthermore, hypocalcemic 
symptoms are more common with respiratory alkalosis.

questions.question:
Question 23: 32 
Sold by @itachibot In the given acid-base nomogram diagram, areas marked A and D indicate which of the 
following conditions?

options.a: Chronic respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis
options.b: Acute Metabolic alkalosis, acute respiratory acidosis
options.c: Acute respiratory acidosis, acute respiratory alkalosis
options.d: Acute respiratory acidosis, acute metabolic alkalosis

questions.explanation:
In the given illustrated acid-base nomogram, the letters A and D indicate acute respiratory 
acidosis and acute respiratory alkalosis. An acid-base nomogram, also known as a Davenport diagram, is a graphical representation of 
acid-base balance to interpret arterial blood gas (ABG) results. It helps determine the primary 
acid-base disorder and identify compensatory mechanisms. 47 
Sold by @itachibot The y-axis of the acid-base nomogram represents the arterial bicarbonate (HCO3-) levels, and the 
x-axis represents the arterial pH values. The shaded areas are the range of values of the normal 
respiratory and metabolic compensations for primary acid-base disturbances.

questions.question:
Question 24: The arterial blood gas analysis findings of a patient are as follows: pH= 7.30, HCO3= 10 
mEq/L, paCO2= 30 mmHg, which is suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. 
What is the mechanism for the secondary disorder?
questions.explanation:
The mechanism for the secondary disorder is hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 washout. The given arterial blood gas findings are suggestive of a partially compensated metabolic acidosis. 
The compensation is partial because the fall in paCO2 much lower than what is expected for the 
given HCO3 levels. The fall in paCO2 is inadequate due to hypoventilation causing decreased CO2 
washout. In this case, the secondary disorder is respiratory acidosis. Hyperventilation causing increased CO2 washout (Option B) would allow for better compensation, 
with lower paCO2 levels than observed. The expected paCO2 can be calculated using Winter's formula: For metabolic acidosis, the expected paCO2 = [1 .5 š HCO3-] + 8 ± 2. Substituting the values, expected PaCO2 = (1.5 x 10) +8 ± 2 = 15+8 ±2 = 21 to 25 mmHg However, the actual PaCO2 is 30 mmHg, which is higher than the expected paCO2 indicating a 
secondary respiratory acidosis. A possible explanation for this could only be hypoventilation 
causing decreased CO2 washout. Thus, the given ABG findings are suggestive of a mixed acid-base disorder characterized by 
metabolic acidosis with additional respiratory acidosis. For example, in a patient with diabetic ketoacidosis and pneumonia, the lungs would fail to 
compensate, and the patient could develop hypoventilation leading to secondary respiratory 48 
Sold by @itachibot acidosis.

questions.question:
Question 25: The arterial blood gas analysis of an unconscious man showed pH- 6.9, HCO3- 13 mEq/L, 
paCO2- 68 mmHg. The acid-base status of this patient is best described as:
questions.explanation:
According to the ABG analysis provided, the patient has a mixed acid-base disorder with 
simultaneous respiratory and metabolic acidosis. Interpretation of the ABG: Step 1: A pH of 6.9 signifies acidosis. Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 13 mEq/L, along with a low pH it signifies metabolic acidosis. Step 3: pCO2 is 68 mmHg indicating co-existing respiratory acidosis. The direction of pCO2 
change is the same as that of pH change suggesting that this is a mixed acid-base disorder. Step 4: The expected compensatory change in pCO2 in the metabolic acidosis calculated using 
Winter's formula would be: pCO2 = [1.5xHCO3-] + 8 ± 2 = 26 - 30 mmHg The actual pCO2 measure is very high (68 mmHg) compared to the estimated range of 26 - 30 
mmHg indicating the presence of simultaneous metabolic and respiratory acidosis. Note- If this was a case of uncompensated acidosis, either the bicarbonate or the pCO2 values 
would have been within the normal limits. 49 
Sold by @itachibot General Principles of Endocrinology
